text: {{c1::\( eg (A \land B) \)}} \( \equiv \) {{c2::\( eg A \lor eg B \)}}
{{c1::\( eg (A \lor B) \) }} \( \equiv \) {{c2::\( eg A \land eg B\)}}
Komplexer Kehrwert: {{c1::\( \frac{1}{z} \)}} \( = \) {{c2::\( \frac{x - iy}{x^2 + y^2}\)}}
{{c1:: Inverse eines Produkts: \((\mathbf{AB})^{-1}\)}} = {{c2::\(\mathbf{B}^{-1} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\)}}
A relation ρ on a set A is called {{c1::reflexive}} if {{c2::\( a \ \rho \ a\) is true for all \( a \in A\), i.e. if \( \text{id} \subseteq \rho\).}}
extra: Example: \( \ge, \le \) are reflexive, while \( <, > \) are not.

text: A relation ρ on a set A is called {{c1::symmetric}} if {{c2::\( a \ \rho \ b \iff b \ \rho \ a\) is true, i.e. if \( \rho = \hat{\rho}\)}}
A relation ρ on a set A is called {{c2::antisymmetric}} if {{c1::\( a \ \rho \ b \wedge b \ \rho \ a \implies a = b\) is true, i.e. if \( \rho \cap \hat{\rho} \subseteq \text{id}\)}}
extra: Example: \( \le, \ge\) and the division relation: \( a \mid b \wedge b \mid a \implies a = b\)

text: A relation is {{c1::transitive}} if {{c2::\((a \ \rho \ b \wedge b \ \rho \ c) \implies a \ \rho \ c \) is true.}}
The {{c2::inverse relation}} is {{c1::\( a \ \rho \ b \iff b \ \hat{\rho} \ a\)}}.
extra: Example: Inverse of parent relation is childhood relation. Also written as \( \rho^{-1}\)

text: Gilt für zwei Matrizen \( \mathbf{A}\) und \( \mathbf{B}\), dass {{c2::\( \mathbf{AB} = \mathbf{BA}\)}}, dann {{c1::kommutieren}} diese Matrizen.
Eine {{c1::Linearkombination (LK)}} der Vektoren \( a_1, \ldots, a_n\) ist {{c2::ein Ausdruck der Form \( \alpha_1 a_1 + \cdots + \alpha_n a_n\) wobei \( \alpha_1, \ldots, \alpha_n \in \mathbb{R}\)}}
Für alle Vektorpaare \( \mathbf{x,y} \in \mathbb{E}^n \) gilt die Schwarzsche Ungleichung: {{c1::\( | \langle \mathbf{x, y} \rangle | \le ||\mathbf{x}|| \ ||\mathbf{y}||\)}}
Ein LGS heisst {{c1::homogen}}, wenn {{c2::die rechte Seite Null ist}}.

{{c1::Eine Gruppe}} ist eine Menge {{c1::G mit Operation \( * \)}} mit folgenden Eigenschaften:
{{c2::
- Assoziotivität: \((a * b) * c = a * (b*c)\)
- Neutrales Element existiert: \( a * e = e * a = e \)
- Inverse existiert: \( a * a^{-1} = a^{-1} * a = e\)
}}
Eine Gruppe \( (G, *) \) heisst {{c1::abelsch (auch: kommutativ)}}, falls \( * \) ausserdem {{c2::\(a * b = b * a\), also das Kommutativitätgesetz erfüllt}}.

{{c1::Ein Körper}} ist eine Menge {{c1::\( \mathbb{K}\) mit Operationen \(+ , *\)}} mit folgenden Eigenschaften:
{{c2::
- \( (\mathbb{K}, +)\) ist eine abelsche Gruppe
- \( (\mathbb{K} \backslash \{0\}, *)\) ist eine abelsche Gruppe
- Distributivität: \( a * (b+c) = a*b + a*c\)
}}
{{c1::Ein Vektorraum}} ist eine Menge \( \mathbb{V}\) über \( \mathbb{K}\), auf der {{c2::eine Addition und eine Skalarmultiplikation definiert ist.}}
extra: Beispiele: \(\mathbb{R}^n, \mathbb{K}^{m\times n}, P_d(\mathbb{K})\) (Polynome von Grad \( \le d\))

text: A function is {{c1::injective (or one-to-one)}} if {{c2::for \(a \ne b\) we have \(f(a) \ne f(b)\), i.e. no "collisions"}}
A function \( f: A \rightarrow B\) is {{c1::surjective (or onto)}} if {{c2::\( \forall b \ \exists a \ , b = f(a)\), i.e. every value is taken}}
A function is {{c1::bijective (one-to-one correspondence)}} if it is {{c2::both injective and surjective.}}
The {{c2::power set of a set \(A\), denoted \(\mathcal{P}(A)\)}}, is {{c1::the set of all subsets of \(A\)}}.

{{c1::Equivalence relation}} is a relation on a set \(A\) that is
{{c2::
* reflexive
* symmetric
* transitive
}}

{{c1::A partial order}} on a set \(A\) is a relation that is
{{c2::
* reflexive
* antisymmetric
* transitive
}}
A set together with a partial order \(\preceq\) is called {{c1::a partially ordered set or simply poset.}}

{{c1::An algebra (also: algebraic structure, \( \Omega\)-algebra)}} is a pair \(\langle S, \Omega \rangle\) {{c2::where S is a set and \(\Omega = (\omega_1, \ldots, \omega_n)\) is a list of operations on S.}}
{{c1::A monoid}} is an algebra {{c2::\( \langle M; *, e \rangle\) where \(*\) is associative and \(e\) is the neutral element.}}
In a poset \( ( A; \preceq )\), \(b\) covers \(a\) if {{c1::\(a \prec b\) and there does not exist a \(c\) with \(a \prec c \land c \prec b \), so no elements are between \(a\) and \(b\).}}
extra: Example: direct superior in a company

text: A poset \((A; \preceq)\) is called {{c2::totally ordered (also: linearly ordered) by \(\preceq\)}} if {{c1::any two elements of the poset are comparable.}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is a {{c1::minimal (maximal) element of \(A\)}} if {{c2::there exists no \(b \in A\) with \(b \prec a\) (\(b \succ a \) )}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is the {{c1::least (greatest) element of \(A\)}} if {{c2::\(a \preceq b\) (\(a \succeq b) \) for all \(b \in A\)}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is a {{c1::lower (upper) bound of \(S\)}} if {{c2::\(b \preceq a\) (\(b \succeq a) \) for all \(b \in S\)}}

Special elements in posets: \((A; \preceq)\) is a poset, \( S \subseteq A\).
\(a \in A\) is the {{c1::greatest lower (least upper) bound of \(S\)}} if {{c2::\(a\) is the greatest (least) element of the set of all lower (upper) bounds of \(S\). }}
A poset \((A;\preceq)\) is well-ordered if {{c1::it is totally ordered and every non-empty subset has a least element.}}
extra:
Every totally ordered finite poset \(\rightarrow\) well-ordered
Infinite example: \((N; \le)\)
Infinite counterexample \((\mathbb{Z}; \le)\)

text: \((A;\preceq)\) is a poset. If \(\{a,b\}\) have a {{c2::greatest lower bound}}, then it is called the {{c1::meet of \(a\) and \(b\) (also denoted \(a \land b\)).}}
\((A;\preceq)\) is a poset. If \(\{a,b\}\) have a {{c2::least upper bound}}, then it is called the {{c1::join of \(a\) and \(b\) (also denoted \(a \lor b\)).}}
A poset in which {{c2::every pair of elements has a meet and a join}} is called a {{c1::lattice}}.
The {{c2::subset \(f(A)\) of \(B\)}} is called the {{c1::image (also: range) of \(f\)}} and is also denoted \(Im(f)\).
extra: Example: \(f(x) = x^2\), the range of \(f\) is \(\mathbb{R}^{\ge 0}\)

text: For a subset \(T\) of \(B\), the {{c1::preimage (in Linalg: Urbild) of \(T\), denoted \(f^{-1}(T)\)}}, is {{c2::the set of values in \(A\) that map into \(T\).}}
extra: Example: \(f(x) = x^2\), the preimage of \([4,9]\) is \([-3,-2] \cup [2,3]\)

text: Two sets \(A, B\) are {{c1::equinumerous (denoted \(A \sim B\))}} if {{c2::there exists a bijection \(A \rightarrow B\).}}
The set \(B\) {{c1::dominates (denoted \(A \preceq B\))}} if {{c2::there exists an injective function \(A \rightarrow B\).}}
A set \(A\) is called countable if {{c1::\(A \preceq \mathbb{N}\)}}, and uncountable otherwise.
\(a \mid b\) means that {{c1::\(a\) divides \(b\), that is, there exists a \(c \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that \(b = ac\)}}
extra: \(\forall a \ne 0 \rightarrow a \mid 0\) and \(\forall a \quad 1 \mid a \land -1 \mid a\)

text: {{c1::\(a \mod m\)}} is the same as {{c2::\(R_m(a)\)}}
\(a  \equiv_m b \stackrel{\text{def}}{\iff}\) {{c1::\(m \mid (a-b)\)}}
The equation \(ax \equiv_m 1\) has a unique solution \(x \in \mathbb{Z}_m\) if and only if {{c1::\(\gcd(a,m) = 1\).}} This \(x\) is then called the multiplicative inverse of \(a \mod m\).

The direct product of \(n\) groups \(\langle G_1; *_1 \rangle, \ldots, \langle G_n; *_n \rangle\) is {{c1::the algebra \(\langle G_1 \times \cdots \times G_n; \star\rangle\)}}. The operation \(\star\) is component-wise.
A subgroup \(H\) of a group \(G\) is {{c1::a subset \(H \subseteq G\) which is a group in itself (closed with respect to all operations).}}
The order of an element \(a\) in a group (denoted \(\text{ord}(a)\)) is {{c1::the smallest \(m \ge 1\) such that \(a^m = e\). If such an \(m\) does not exist, \(\text{ord}(a) = \infty\)}}
For a finite group \(G\), we call \(|G|\) the {{c1::order of \(G\)}}.
A group \(G = \langle g \rangle\) generated by an element \(g \in G\) is called {{c1::cyclic}}, and \(g\) is called {{c1::a generator of \(G\)}}.
If \(G\) is a finite group and \(H\) is a subgroup, then {{c1::the order of \(H\) divides the order of \(G\), i.e. \(|H|\) divides \(|G|\).}}
The group \(\mathbb{Z}^*_m\) contains all numbers \(a \in \mathbb{Z}_m\) that are {{c1::coprime to \(m\), that is, \(\gcd(a,m) = 1\).}}
The Euler function \(\varphi: \mathbb{Z}^+ \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}^+\) is defined as {{c1::the cardinality of \(\mathbb{Z}^*_m\).}}
In graph theory, a {{c1::walk}} is a {{c2::series of connected vertices}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::path}} is a {{c1::walk without repeated vertices}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::closed walk}} is a {{c1::walk where \(v_0 = v_n\) (start = end)}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::cycle}} is a {{c1::closed walk without repeated vertices}}.
In graph theory, an {{c2::Euler path}} is a {{c1::path that visits each edge of the graph once}}.
In graph theory, a {{c2::Hamilton path}} is a {{c1::path that visits each vertex of the graph once}}.

{{c1::A ring \(\langle R, +, -, 0, \cdot, 1 \rangle\)}} is an algebra with the properties that
{{c2::* \(\langle R, +, -, 0 \rangle\) is a commutative group}}
{{c3::* \(\langle R, \cdot, 1 \rangle\) is a monoid}}
{{c4::* \( a(b+c) = (ab) + (ac), (b+c)a = (ba) + (ca)\) (left and right distributive laws)}}
A ring is called {{c1::commutative}} if {{c2::\(ab = ba\).}}
An element \(u\) of a ring is called a {{c1::unit}} if \(u\) {{c2::is invertible, so \(uu^{-1} = u^{-1}u = 1\).}}
The set of units of \(R\) is denoted by {{c1::\(R^*\)}}
An {{c1::integral domain}} is a {{c2::commutative ring without zerodivisors (\( \forall a \ \forall b \quad ab = 0 \rightarrow a = 0 \lor b = 0\) ).}}
A {{c1::field (Körper)}} is {{c2::a nontrivial commutative ring \(F\) in which every nonzero element is a unit, so \(F^* = F \backslash \{0\}\)}}
\(\mathbb{Z}_p\) is a field if and only if {{c1::\(p\) is prime.}}
A {{c1::root (also: zero)}} of \(a(x) \in \mathbb{R}[x]\) is {{c2::an element \(y \in \mathbb{R}\) for which \(a(y) = 0\).}}
extra: Example: \(x^4 + x^3 + x + 1\) in GF(2)\([x]\) has root 1.

text: In a field F, \(y \in F\) is a root of \(a(x)\) if and only if {{c1::\(x - y\) divides \(a(x)\).}}
The idea of {{c2::Universal Instantiation}} is that {{c1::if a statement is true for all elements, it is also true for a particular element, so \(\forall x F \models F[x/t]\).}}
extra: Example: All elements in \(\mathbb{R}\) are invertible. Thus, 2 is also invertible.

text: Predicate logic: A formula in {{c2::prenex form}} has {{c1::all quantifiers in front and none afterwards. }}

DFS

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| + |V|) \)}}

Approach: {{c1::We first go through the depth of each node. We might keep track of pre / post numbers to make edge classifications.}}

Uses: {{c1::Detect cycles (if backward edge), path finding, topological sorting, test if bipartite, mazes, ...}}

BFS

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| + |V|) \)}}

Approach: {{c1::We first go through all direct successors of an edge, then move to a level deeper.}}

Uses: {{c1::Shortest path in unweighted graphs, cycle detection, test if graph is bipartite, path finding}}

Dijkstra

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}((|E| + |V|) \cdot log(|V|)) \)}}

Approach: {{c1::We put the starting node into the queue, take it out, and set the distance for all adjacent nodes and put them into the queue. We repeat, update distances and only put nodes into the queue if they weren't visited before.}}

Uses: {{c1::Minimal-cost paths in non-negative weighted directed graphs}}

Bellman-Ford

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| \cdot |V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c1::We initiate all distances with ∞. Then we go |V| - 1 times through every edge, and test for all (u,v) in E if dist[v] > dist[u] + w(u,v). If yes, we update the distance. If after [V] - 1 iterations we can still relax an edge (in a last iteration), then there exists a negative cycle.}}

Uses: {{c1::Detect negative cycles, find minimal-cost paths in weighted graphs with negative weights}}

Boruvka

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}((|E| + |V|) \cdot log(|V|))\)}}

Approach: {{c1::We first add all vertices to the set of components (so every vertices has its own component). Then as long as the size of the components-set is greater than 1, we connect each component to the one with the cheapest edge.}}

Uses: {{c1::Find MST in weighted, undirected graph}}

Kruskal

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| \cdot log(|E|) + |E| \cdot log(|V|))\)}}

Approach: {{c1::We sort the edges by weight and add them one-by-one as long as they are in different components.}}

Uses: {{c1::Find MST in weighted, undirected graph}}

Prim

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}((|E| + |V|) \cdot log(|V|))\)}}

Approach: {{c1::We start at a given vertex. To this subtree we add one-by-one the cheapest edge connecting the subtree to another component until all vertices are connected. The implementation is very similar to Dijkstra.}}

Uses: {{c1::Find MST in weighted, undirected graph}}

Floyd-Warshall

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|V|^3)\)}}

Approach: {{c1::3D DP: It is based on a triple-nested for loop with the following recursion: d[u][v] = min(d[u][v], d[u][i] + d[i][v]).}}

Uses: {{c1::All-to-all shortest path in directed graph without negative cycles.}}

Johnson

Runtime: {{c1::\( \mathcal{O}(|E| \cdot |V| + |V|^2 \cdot log(|V|)\)}}

Approach: {{c1::We make all edges positive and then perform n-times Dijkstra. To do this we create an additional node that is linked to each node with edge weight 0 and store for each node a height h(x), where h(x) is equal to the shortest path from the new node n to the node x. The new weights are calculated with w'(u,v) = w(u,v) + h(u) - h(v).}}

Uses: {{c1::All-to-all shortest paths in directed graphs without negative cycles.}}
A graph \(G = (V,E)\) is k-connected (k-zusammenhängend) if {{c1::you need to remove at least \(k\) vertices from the graph such that it becomes disconnected.}}
extra: This graph is 2-connected. We need to remove 2 vertices to make the graph disconnected.

text: A graph \(G=(V,E)\) is \(k\)-edge-connected (k-kanten-zusammenhängend) if {{c1::we need to remove at least \(k\) edges from \(G\) such that it becomes disconnected.}}
extra: This graph is 2-edge-connected, we must remove 2 edges to make it disconnected.

text: A \(u\)-\(v\)-separator is {{c1::a set \(X\) of vertices such that \(u, v\) are in different components after we remove these edges from \(G\), so in \(G[V \ \backslash \ X]\).}}
\(G = (V,E)\) is \(k\)-connected iff \(|V| \ge k + 1\) (otherwise not sensible) and every \(u\)-\(v\)-separator has {{c1::size \(|X| \ge k\).}}

(Menger's theorem)
{{c2::Every \(u\)-\(v\)-separator \(X\) has size \(|X| \ge k\) }} \(\iff\) {{c1::There exist \(k\) internally vertex-disjoint paths (i.e. they share no vertices) between \(u, v\).}}
A lock is reentrant if {{c1::it can be acquired / released multiple times by the same thread.}}
extra: If a lock is non-reentrant, when trying to acquire it again exceptions or other problems might occur.

text: A thread starves if {{c1::it can never enter a critical section}}.

{{c3::Die geometrische Reihe}} konvergiert für \(|q| < 1\):

{{c1::\(\sum_{k=0}^\infty q^k\)}} \(=\) {{c2::\(\frac{1}{1-q}\)}}
Die harmonische Reihe \(\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{n}\) {{c1::divergiert.}}
In a one-hot encoding, all {{c1::values are low (0) except one (1)}}.
In a binary encoding, {{c1::each state is represented as a binary number.}}
extra:
Advantage: very compact, reduces amount of Flip-Flops used for state
Disadvantage: other logic more complicated

text: In an Output encoding, {{c1::outputs are directly accessible in state encoding.}}
extra:
Example: 001, 010, 100, 110 for a (green, yellow, red) traffic light
Advantage: minimizes output logic

text: R-type instructions operate on {{c1::three registers}}
I-type instructions operate on {{c1::two registers and a 16-bit immediate.}}
J-type instructions operate on {{c1::one 26-bit immediate.}}
In Boolean algebra, \(\bullet\) means {{c1::AND}}.
In Boolean algebra, \(+\) means {{c1::OR}}.
Ein Graph ist \(k\)-zusammenhängend, wenn {{c1::wir mindestens \(k\) Knoten löschen müssen, damit er nicht mehr zusammenhängend ist.}}
Wenn ein Graph \(k\)-zusammenhängend ist, ist er auch {{c1::\(k-1\)-zusammenhängend.}}
Es gibt {{c1::\(n^k\)}} Möglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente geordnet mit Zurücklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) zu ziehen.
Es gibt {{c1::\(\frac{n!}{(n-k)!}\)}} Möglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente geordnet ohne Zurücklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) Elementen zu ziehen.
Es gibt {{c1::\(\binom{n+k-1}{k}\)}} Möglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente ungeordnet mit Zurücklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) Elementen zu ziehen.
Es gibt {{c1::\(\binom{n}{k}\)}} Möglichkeiten, \(k\) Elemente ungeordnet ohne Zurücklegen aus einer Menge mit \(n\) Elementen zu ziehen.
Ein induzierter Teilgraph entsteht, wenn man aus einem Graph {{c1::nur Knoten & dessen verbundene Kanten entfernt. }} Man darf also nicht {{c1::nur Kanten entfernen}}.
Eine {{c2::endliche, nichtleere Menge \(\Sigma\)}} heisst {{c1::Alphabet}}.
Das leere Wort in einem Alphabet \(\Sigma\) wird mit {{c1::\(\lambda\)}} bezeichnet.
The order of the differential equation is {{c1::the order of the highest derivative in the equation}}.
A differential equation is called homogenous if {{c1::its right hand side is 0}}.

Ein deterministischer endlicher Automat (EA) ist ein Tupel \(M = (Q, \Sigma, \delta, q_0, F)\) wobei
  • Q {{c1::eine endliche Menge von Zuständen}}
  • \(\Sigma\) {{c2::ein Eingabealphabet}}
  • \(q_0 \in Q\) {{c3::der Anfangszustand}}
  • \(\delta : Q \times \Sigma \to Q\) {{c4::die Übergangsfunktion}}
  • \(F \subseteq Q\) {{c5::die Menge der akzeptierenden Zustände}}
ist.
\(\delta(q,a) = p\) bedeutet, {{c1::dass \(M\) in den Zustand \(p\) übergeht, falls \(M\) im Zustand \(q\) das Symbol \(a\) gelesen hat}}
Die Klasse der regulären Sprachen \(\mathcal{L}_{EA}\) ist die Klasse der Sprachen, {{c1::welche von einem endlichen Automaten akzeptiert werden.}}
A useful equation for avoiding cancellation is \(a - b = \) {{c1::\(\frac{a^2 - b^2}{a+b}\)}}
A useful equation for avoiding cancellation is \(\log a - \log b = \) {{c1::\(\log \frac{a}{b}\)}}
A trap is {{c1::an intentional synchronous exception}}.
A fault is an {{c1::unintential but potentially recoverable synchronous}} exception.
extra: Examples: page faults, floating point exceptions

text: An abort is an {{c1::unintentional and unrecoverable}} exception.
An interrupt is an {{c1::asychronous signal from an I/O device}}.
A page fault happens when {{c1::a user accesses a location in memory that is not in physical memory}}.
If an interrupt is maskable, we can {{c1::choose to ignore or delay it}}.
IOMMU stands for {{c1::I/O Memory Management Unit}}.
SAT = {{c1::\(\{\Phi \mid \Phi \) ist eine erfüllbare Formel in KNF\(\}\) }}
CLIQUE = {{c1::\(\{(G,k) \mid G \) ist ein ungerichteter Graph, der eine \(k\)-Clique enthält \(\}\)}}
Eine \(k\)-Clique in einem Graphen ist {{c1::ein Subset an Knoten der Grösse \(k\), welche alle paarweise verbunden sind.}}
VC = {{c1::\(\{(G,k) \mid G\) ist ein Graph mit Knotenüberdeckung der Grösse höchstens \(k \}\)}}
The TLB ({{c1::Translation Lookaside Buffer}}) is a {{c1::cache for mapping virtual page numbers to physical page numbers.}}
PTE stands for {{c1::Page Table Entry.}}
\(L_U = \) {{c1::\(\{\text{Kod}(M)\#w \mid w \in \{0,1\}^* \text{ und M akzeptiert } w\}\)}}
\(L_H = \) {{c1::\(\{\text{Kod}(M)\# x \mid x \in \{0,1\}^*\)  und M hält auf \(x\}\)}}
\(L_{\text{empty}} =\) {{c1::\(\{\text{Kod}(M) \mid L(M) = \varnothing \}\)}}
\(L_{EQ} =\) {{c1::\(\{\text{Kod}(M)\#\text{Kod}(\bar{M}) \mid L(M) = L(\bar{M})\}\)}}
\(L_{H,\lambda} =\) {{c1::\(\{\text{Kod}(M) \mid M \text{ hält auf } \lambda \}\)}}
Der Satz von Cook besagt, dass {{c1::SAT NP-vollständig ist.}}
Eine Grammatik ist eine Typ-3-Grammatik (regulär), falls {{c1::\(\forall (\alpha,\beta) \in P: \alpha \in \Sigma_N, \beta \in \Sigma_T^* \times \Sigma_N \cup \Sigma_T^*\).}}
extra: d.h. nur ein Nichtterminal und Terminale nur als Prefix

text: Eine Grammatik ist eine Typ-2-Grammatik (kontextfrei), falls {{c1::\(\forall (\alpha, \beta) \in P: \alpha \in \Sigma_N, \beta \in (\Sigma_N \cup \Sigma_T)^*\).}}
Eine Grammatik ist eine Typ-1-Grammatik (kontextsensitiv), falls {{c1::\(\forall (\alpha, \beta) \in P: |\alpha| \le |\beta|\).}}
Der Satz von Rice besagt, dass {{c1::jedes semantisch nichttriviale Entscheidungsproblem über Turingmaschinen unentscheidbar ist.}}
extra:
semantisch: unabhängig von Struktur der TM
nichttrivial: mindestens 1 aber nicht alle TM sind in der Sprache

text: Eine Sprache \(L\) ist NP-schwer, wenn {{c1::alle Sprachen in NP in polynomieller Zeit auf \(L\) reduziert werden können.}}
Eine Sprache \(L\) ist NP-vollständig, falls {{c1::\(L \in\) NP und \(L\) NP-schwer ist.}}
A compilation unit in C is roughly {{c1::a source file plus all of its includes.}}
Referential transparency means that {{c1::an expression always evaluates to the same value in every context}}.
A Candidate Key is {{c1::the minimal set of fields that identifies each tuple in a relation uniquely.}}
A Primary Key is {{c1::a chosen candidate key.}}
extra: intutitively: unique identifier for data row

text: In Relational Algebra, the \(\sigma\) operator means {{c1::Selection, so basically WHERE.}}
In Relational Algebra, the \(\prod\) operator means {{c1::Projection, so we select a subset of columns.}}
In Relational Algebra, the \(\rho\) operator means {{c1::Renaming, so we change the name of the attributes.}}
In Relational Algebra, the \(\bowtie\) operator means {{c1::Natural Join, so join on all common attributes.}}
In TCP congestion control, slow start is {{c1::a phase in which we enlarge the CWND by 1 per received ACK.}}
extra: If all packets make it, this leads to a doubling of the CWND per RTT!

text: In TCP congestion control, a timeout causes the CWND to {{c1::be reset to 1.}}
In TCP congestion control, fast recovery causes CWND {{c1::to be halved.}}
The Karn/Partridge-Algorithm estimates {{c1::Round Trip Times for setting good timeouts}}.
The Jacobson/Karels algorithm is an improvement over the {{c1::Karn/Partridge}} algorithm.
The loopback address in IPv6 is {{c1::⠶1/128.}}
"Happy Eyeballs" is a networking algorithm that says that {{c1::clients should try both IPv4 and IPv6, but prefer an IPv6 connection to a server if available.}}

The 4 goals of reliable transfer are:
  • {{c1::Correctness}}
  • {{c2::Timeliness}}
  • {{c3::Efficiency}}
  • {{c4::Fairness}}
A reliable transport design is correct if {{c1::a packet is always resent if the previous packet was lost/corrupted.}}

To download a file with curl, use {{c1::
curl -O
}}
In an OS, a trampoline is a {{c1::part of the memory that is at the same address in both the user and kernel page tables.}}

The Operating System is defined as the body of software that
  • {{c1::Multiplexes hardware resources}}
  • {{c2::Abstracts the hardware away}}
  • {{c3::Protects programs from each other}}

The three roles of an OS are to be {{c1::
  • Referee
  • Illusionist
  • Glue
    • }}
A name is an {{c1::identifier for an object in a system}}.
A binding is an {{c1::association of a name to an object}}.
A context is a {{c1::set of bindings}}. Also known as {{c1::namespace or name scope}}.
Resolution is {{c1::the process of taking a name + context and finding the object bound to the name in that context}}.
extra: The bound object could also be a new context.

text: A naming network is a {{c1::directed graph where nodes are either contexts or objects, and the edges are bindings}}.
A pathname is a {{c1::ordered list of names (called path components) that specify a path in a naming network}}.
The central nervous system (CNS) is made up of {{c1::the brain and the spinal cord.}}
The cerebral cortex is the {{c1::superficial gray matter of the brain hemispheres.}}
The corpus callosum is {{c1::the large midline fiber bundle connecting the two brain hemispheres.}}
Gray matter is a term describing {{c1::regions of the CNS with many neuronal cell bodies, dendrites and synapses.}}
extra: It's gray because there isn't much myelin in the gray matter, and the myelin is white.

text: The gyrus are {{c1::the ridges of the infolded cerebral cortex.}}
The limbic system is {{c1::the part of the brain concerned with emotions.}}
The neocortex is the {{c1::six-layered cortex that makes up about 90% of the cerebral cortex.}}
The peripheral nervous system (PNS) includes {{c1::all nerves and neurons outside the brain & spinal cord.}}
The soma is {{c1::the cell body of a neuron.}}

In scheduling, priority inversion is {{c1::a problem where a low-priority task holds a lock that a high-priority task needs. Then a middle-priority task gets scheduled instead, and the high-priority task is unable to run.}}
extra: This happened on the Mars Pathfinder rover.

text: A preemptive scheduler may {{c1::interrupt and suspend a task before it is completed.}}
In scheduling, priority inheritance is {{c1::a solution to the priority inversion problem. If a task holds a lock, it temporarily has the priority of the highest process waiting for the lock.}}
extra: This requires the scheduler to be involved in lock operations.

text: In scheduling, priority ceiling is {{c1::a solution to the priority inversion problem. If a task holds a lock, it temporarily has the priority of the highest process which can ever hold the lock.}}
extra: This can require static analysis of the entire system.

text: The Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation is used to determine the {{c1::reversal potential across a membrane including all permeable ions.}}
An afferent neuron/axon conducts action potentials {{c1::from the periphery towards the CNS}}.
An efferent neuron/axon conducts action potentials {{c1::away from the CNS to the periphery.}}
The presynaptic terminal is also called {{c1::axon terminal or bouton}}.
The Nodes of Ranvier are {{c1::myelin-sheath gaps along the axon where the action potential is regenerated}}.
The meninges are {{c1::the three membranes that surround and protect the brain / spinal cord}}.
The dura mater is {{c1::the thick inelastic outermost layer of the meninges}}.
The arachnoid mater is {{c1::the thin middle layer of the meninges}}.
extra: Among other things, it keeps blood from getting into the cerebrospinal fluid.

text: The pia mater is {{c1::the thin innermost layer of the meninges}}.
extra: Among other things, it prevents cerebrospinal fluid from reaching the brain.

text:
The CAP theorem says that any distributed system {{c1::can only have two of the three properties:
  • Consistency
  • Availability
  • Partition tolerance}}
The shared state in Bitcoin is {{c1::the set of unspent transaction outputs (UTXOs) and some additional global parameters.}}
The Bitcoin PoW function is given by {{c1::\[\mathcal{F}_d(c,x) \to \text{SHA256}(\text{SHA256}(c|x)) < \frac{2^{224} }{d}\]}}
On success, <tt>fork()</tt> returns {{c1::the child PID}} to the parent and {{c1::0}} to the child.
On failure, <tt>fork()</tt> returns {{c1::-1}} to the parent and the child {{c1::is not created}}.
The drift \(\delta\) is {{c1::the predictable clock error}}.
TAI is a {{c1::time standard without leap seconds}}.

Caller-save registers are {{c1::"volatile" across a call - the caller must save them}}. In constrast, callee-save registers are {{c1::"non-volatile" across a call - the called function must restore them}}.
A naming hierarchy is a {{c1::naming network that is a tree}}.
An indirect entry is a {{c1::name bound to another path name}}.
extra: The other path name is resolved in the same context as the indirect entry.

text: A pure name tells us {{c1::nothing useful about the object it refers to}}.
An address is a name that {{c1::also encodes information about the object it refers to}}.
A search path is an {{c1::ordered list of contexts that are treated like a single context}}.
extra: e.g. the $PATH variable on Linux. We go through all the contexts until we find a binding for the given name.

text: Synonyms are {{c1::different names bound to the same object}}.

Bootstrapping (also called booting) is the process {{c1::of starting the operating system when the machine is powered on / reset}}. It ends when {{c1::the operating system is running regular processes}}.

A computer boots by doing four steps:
  1. {{c1::CPU starts executing code at a fixed address, where the Boot ROM is.}}
  2. {{c2::The Boot ROM code loads the second stage boot loader into RAM.}}
  3. {{c3::The second stage boot loader loads the kernel and (sometimes) an initial file system into RAM.}}
  4. {{c4::Jump to the kernel entry point.}}
In user mode, we have {{c1::limited}} privileges.
extra: e.g. we cannot write to any memory

text: We switch from user mode to kernel mode when {{c1::a processor exception happens (e.g. a syscall trap or a page fault)}}.

When an exception occurs, we
  1. {{c1::Finish executing the current instruction}}.
  2. {{c2::Switch to kernel mode}}
  3. {{c3::Look up exception cause in the exception vector table}}
  4. {{c4::Jump to the address from the table}}
A synchronous exception happens because {{c1::we execute an instruction}}.
The kernel is {{c1::the code that runs in kernel mode}}.
A system library is {{c1::a convenient interface to the kernel}}.
A daemon is {{c1::a user-space process which provides OS services}}.
IPC stands for {{c1::Inter-Process Communication}}.
A hardware timer regularly {{c1::causes an interrupt that returns control to the kernel handler}}.
Homonyms are {{c1::the same name being bound to different objects}}.
While the interrupt handler runs, interrupts {{c1::are turned off}}.
A process is {{c1::the execution of a program with restricted rights}}.
A thread is {{c1::a sequence of instructions within a process}}.
The name of a process is {{c1::its PID}}.
The Process Control Block (PCB) is a {{c1::data structure holding information about a process}}.
There are two main approaches for creating a process: {{c1::spawn}} and {{c2::fork/exec}}.
The trap frame contains {{c1::values of certain registers saved there before a syscall is handled}}.
The kernel switches processes when either {{c1::a timer interrupts it}} or when {{c1::a process blocks}}.
One of the main purposes of the init process is to {{c1::wait for any child to exit() so that there are no orphans}}.
The two ways for processes to communicate are through {{c1::message passing}} or through {{c2::shared memory}}.
Marshalling is {{c1::the process of converting data into a format suitable for transmission}}.
extra: e.g. arguments in a RPC are marshalled.

text: A zombie is a {{c1::process that has died, but is still around because its parent hasn't called wait().}}
A zombie process has to continue to exist because {{c1::the exit status must be preserved}}.

We need only three concepts to build all OS structures:
  • {{c1::Mode switch}}
  • {{c2::Page tables}}
  • {{c3::Timer interrupts}}
Uniprocessor scheduling is {{c1::the problem of scheduling tasks on a single processor core}}.
Batch scheduling is {{c1::the problem of scheduling a (potentially unbounded) set of finite tasks}}.
The execution time (or run time) of a job is {{c1::the time it takes for the job to execute once started}}.
The hold time of a job is {{c1::the time it takes for the job from arriving at the scheduler to start executing}}.
The wait time of a job is {{c1::the total time it takes from arriving to finishing the job}}.
The arrival time (or release time) of a job is {{c1::the time where it arrives at the scheduler}}.
In scheduling, First Come First Served (FCFS) works by always dispatching the job {{c1::with the earliest arrival time.}}
The convoy phenomenon is a problem in scheduling where {{c1::many short jobs are stalled because of a long-running job, which inflates mean wait times}}.
Multi-level feedback queues is a class of scheduling algorithms that {{c1::penalize CPU-bound tasks in favor of I/O-bound tasks}}.
The aim of multi-level feedback queue algorithms is to {{c1::get good response times for interactive jobs and good throughput for background jobs}}.
In scheduling, Earliest Deadline First works by dispatching the job that {{c1::has the earliest deadline}}.
extra: Would be implemented with a Priority Queue to work in \(\mathcal{O}(\log n)\)

text: Reservation-based scheduling guarantees {{c1::a minimum amount of CPU time to each job.}}
A scheduler is work conserving if {{c1::no processor is ever idle when there is a runnable task.}}
The First-level Interrupt Service Routine (FLISR) is {{c1::the code that executes immediately as a result of a (device) interrupt}}.
A character device is used for {{c1::unstructured}} IO and we access {{c1::single bytes in a byte-stream}}.
A block device is used for {{c1::structured}} IO and we access {{c1::whole blocks, e.g. disk blocks}}.
The Process Control Block must contain at least {{c1::the page table, trap frame, kernel stack, open files, program name, scheduling state, PID}}.
Affinity scheduling is the idea that {{c1::we should schedule jobs on the same core as much as possible}}.
A deferred procedure call (DPC, also known as soft interrupt handler) is {{c1::a program created by the first-level interrupt handler to handle a device interrupt}}.
With base and limit registers, programs had to be compiled to {{c1::position-independent code}} because {{c1::the base address is not known at compile time}}.
A disadvantage of relocation registers is that they do not allow {{c1::sharing code / data}}.
With segmentation, each process has a {{c1::segment table containing segments (offset + size)}}.
An advantage of segmentation for MMU is that we can {{c1::share code/data between processes}}.
A disadvantage of segmentation for MMU is {{c1::external fragmentation - wasted space}}.
With zero-on-reference, we {{c1::zero the memory when allocated}} to avoid {{c2::leaking information}}.
With fill-on-demand, we can {{c2::start a program before its code is in physical memory}} by {{c1::bringing in pages from disk when needed}}.
Copy-on-write (COW) optimizes {{c1::copying large regions of virtual memory}}.
When calling fork() with Copy-on-write, we {{c1::copy the page table and set all mappings to read-only in both address spaces}}.
When we write to a read-only page with copy-on-write, we {{c1::allocate a new page, copy the contents, and change the mapping to the new page}}.
Bélády's Anomaly is the anomaly that {{c1::for some replacement algorithms increasing cache size can reduce the hit rate for certain access patterns}}.
The clock (or second chance) replacement policy approximates {{c1::LRU}}, but {{c2::is much cheaper}}.
A security principal or subject is {{c1::an entity to which we give access rights}}.
The protection domain of a principal is {{c1::the set of objects for which the principal has some rights}}.
The access control matrix is a table where {{c2::the rows are principals and the columns are objects}}. A cell is {{c1::a list of the rights the principal has over the object}}.
An access control list (ACL) is a {{c1::list for a column of the access control list, so a set of the rights principals have over an object}}.
Cranial nerves are the nerves {{c1::emerging directly from the brain}} and connect to {{c2::our primary senses (vision / taste / smell / hearing)}}.
The ventricular system is {{c1::a set of four holes (cerebral ventricles) in the brain}}. In there {{c2::the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)}} is produced.
The basal ganglia is a {{c1::part of the brain that is (among other things) involved in voluntary movement}}.
The thalamus is a {{c1::large mass of gray matter that also acts as a relay for sensory signals}}.
The hypothalamus is {{c1::a part of the brain that connects the nervous system to the hormone system}}.
The cerebellum ("little brain") is a {{c1::part of the brain that is important for motor control}}.
Camillo Golgi discovered a {{c1::technique to stain neurons in nervous tissue}}.
Hodgkin and Huxley were able to {{c1::describe how ionic currents caused the action potential}}.
When neurotransmitter vesicles undergo priming, {{c2::they become ready to be released}}. This corresponds to {{c1::the assembly of the SNARE complex}}.
SNARE complexes are {{c1::protein structures which help with vesicle priming & fusion}}.
Hebb's law says that {{c1::neurons that fire together, wire together}}.
The axon hillock is the {{c1::part of the soma that connects to the axon}}.
In the axon hillock, {{c1::potentials are summed and if a threshold is exceeded, an action potential propagates through the axon}}.
When the action potential arrives at the presynaptic terminal, {{c2::voltage-gated \(Ca^{2+}\) channels are opened}}, which cause {{c1::neurotransmitter to be released}}.
Long-term potentiation (LTP) is {{c1::a strengthening of synapses}} and happens {{c2::after short but high-frequency stimulation}}.
Long Term Depression (LTD) is {{c2::a weakening of synapses}} and happens after {{c1::long but low frequency stimulation}}.
A Hopfield network consists of {{c1::multiple McCulloch-Pitts neurons that are fully connected}}.
The receptor {{c1::NMDA}} is critically involved in Long-Term Potentiation.
Population codes are {{c1::neural representations at the level of groups of cells}}.
The association cortex is the part of the cerebral cortex that is {{c1::not involved in sensory / motor processing}}.
Potassium is a chemical element called {{c1::Kalium}} in German.
Sodium is a chemical element called {{c1::Natrium}} in German.
In an asynchronous environment, a message will {{c1::arrive in a finite but unbounded time}}.
Any-Input validity says that {{c1::the decision value must be the input of any node}}.
All-Same Validity says that {{c1::if all nodes start with the same input, that must be the decision value}}.
A network with \(n\) nodes cannot reach byzantine agreement with {{c1:: \(f \ge \frac{n}{3}\)}} byzantine nodes.

The King algorithm has three phases:{{c1::
  1. Vote (broadcast value)
  2. Propose (if a value is received often, propose it)
  3. King (if few proposals, follow the king)
}}
In a distributed system, churn is {{c1::how much nodes are joining and leaving the system}}.
A quorum is a {{c1::subset of nodes of a system}}.
A quorum system is a {{c1::set of quorums such that every two quorums intersect}}.
In the Majority quorum system, {{c1::every quorum has \(\lfloor\frac{n}{2}\rfloor +1\)  nodes}}.
An access strategy \(Z\) defines {{c1::the probability \(P_Z(Q)\)  of accessing a quorum \(Q \in S\)  such that \(\sum_{Q\in S}P_Z(Q) = 1\) .}}
The work of a quorum is {{c1::the number of nodes in it}}.
The resilience of a quorum system is {{c1::the largest number of nodes that can fail such that there's always a quorum without failed nodes}}.
Every quorum system has a load of at least {{c1::\(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n} }\)}}.
A uniform quorum system is one in which {{c1::all quorums have the same number of nodes}}.
The load in a (B-)grid quorum system is {{c1::\(\Theta(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n} })\), which is optimal}}.
The Precise Time Protocol (PTP) is similar to NTP, but {{c1::uses MAC layer timestamps}}.
A logical volume can {{c1::merge multiple physical devices into a single volume}}.
The superblock is the {{c1::area of a disk which holds information about the layout of the file system (how large, where inode tables are, etc.)}}.
extra: In FAT: the Master Boot Record

text: A virtual machine monitor does {{c1::virtualize an entire machine}}.
A Type-1 hypervisor runs {{c1::directly on the hardware}}.
A Type-2 hypervisor runs {{c1::on a conventional OS like normal software}}.
A paravirtualized guest OS is one that {{c1::has been modified for running inside a VM}}.
extra: Fast, but cannot run arbitrary OS binaries

text: Virtualization with binary rewriting {{c1::patches the kernel on the fly to remove unvirtualizable instructions}}.
With directly writable tables, a guest OS can {{c1::create page tables the hardware uses to directly translate virtual adresses to machine addresses}}.
With directly writable tables, the VMM has to {{c1::check all writes to page table entries, such that the guest cannot escape the VM}}.
A strategy profile is a social optimum if it {{c1::minimizes the sum of all costs (or maximizes payoff)}}.
A Nash Equilibrirum is a {{c1::strategy profile where nobody can improve their strategy alone (without others changing)}}.
The Price of Anarchy is {{c1::the ratio between the Nash Equilibrium with the highest cost (smallest payoff) and the social optimum}}.
The Optimistic Price of Anarchy is {{c1::the ratio between the Nash Equilibrium with the smallest cost (highest payoff) and the social optimum}}.
Braess's paradox says that {{c1::adding one or more roads to a road network can slow down overall traffic flow}}.
A ticket is a weaker form of a lock that {{c1::can be reissued and that expires (if a new ticket was issued since by a server, the old one is no longer accepted)}}.
Paxos cannot make progress anymore if {{c1::half or more of the servers crash}}.
There is no deterministic algorithm that achieves consensus in {{c1::the asynchronous model for \(f > 0\).}}
A transaction with a timelock is {{c1::not released into the network until the timelock expires}}.
The diameter of a graph is the {{c1::longest shortest path}}.
The span of a set of vectors is {{c1::the set of all possible linear combinations of them}}.
extra: The span is a linear subspace.

text: The p-norm of a vector \(x \in \mathbb{R}^n\) is defined as {{c1::\(||x||_p=\left(\sum_{i=1}^n |x_i|^p\right)^{1/p}\)}}.
The loss function \(l(f(x),y)\) tells us {{c1::how good the predicted value \(f(x)\) is compared to the true value \(y\)}}.
The training loss \(L(f)\) is {{c1::the average loss over the training set for a predictor \(f\).}}
The flyweight pattern {{c1::minimizes memory usage and coupling}} by {{c2::sharing data of (often immutable) objects.}}
In the Observer Pattern, the subject has {{c1::a list of dependents (observers) and notifies them of state changes through calling a method.}}

In the Model-View-Controller architecture, 
  • the model {{c1::contains core functionality & data}}
  • the views {{c2::display information to the user}}
  • the controllers {{c3::handle user input}}
A disadvantage of event-based architectures is that we {{c1::lose control (who responds, in what order, etc.)}}.
The Strategy Pattern allows {{c1::selecting an algorithm / option at runtime}}.
extra: e.g. different filters depending on type

text: An advantage of holding out less data (smaller test set) is that we are {{c1::more likely to get a better model}}.
An advantage of holding out more data (larger test set) is that we are {{c1::able to better estimate the generalization error}}.
The training set is used to {{c1::find the best parameters of a given method}}.
The validation set is used to {{c1::find the best method}}.
The test set is used to {{c1::check how good our model performs}}.
Underfitting is driven by the {{c1::bias}}.
Overfitting is driven by the {{c1::variance}}.
Lasso regression limits the {{c1::\(l_1\)-norm}}.
Ridge regression limits the {{c1::\(l_2\)-norm}}.
In classification, precision is {{c1::the number of true positives over the number of elements labelled as positive}}.
In classification, recall is the {{c1::number of true positives divided by the number of actually positive elements}}.
A complete lattice is a poset where {{c1::every subset has a least upper and greatest lower bound.}}
Coupling measures {{c1::how much modules depend on each other}}.
Procedural Coupling: Modules are coupled to other modules {{c1::whose methods they call}}.
An event-based style (e.g. MVC) helps with {{c1::procedural}} coupling.
Class Coupling: {{c1::Inheritance}} couples a class to another class.
The "Fragile base class problem" is an OOP problem where {{c1::seemingly safe modifications to a base class may break subclasses}}.
By using interfaces, we can often reduce {{c1::class}} coupling.
We can reduce class coupling from allocations by delegating these to a so-called {{c1::abstract factory}}.
We can prepare modules for future change by {{c1::parametrizing}} them.
The vanishing gradient problem is a problem in machine learning where {{c1::during training the gradient becomes very small, which prevents our weights from changing & further training}}.
The softmax function is often used in the {{c2::final}} layer of a {{c1::neural network-based classifier}}.
A gradient descent iteration updates \(w^{next}\) to be {{c1::\(w^{now} -\eta\cdot\nabla L(w^{now})\).}}
In gradient descent, \(\eta\) is the {{c1::learning rate}}.
The closed form solution of d-dim linear regression for \(w_{min}\) is {{c1::\((X^TX)^{-1}X^Ty\).}}
In gradient descent, momentum incorporates {{c2::the gradient of the previous step}} to {{c1::remove oscillations and speed up convergence}}.
Minibatch SGD uses {{c2::a subset of points}}, whereas normal SGD uses {{c1::just one point}}.
The logistic loss is defined as \(g_{log}(y\hat{f}(x)) =\){{c1::\(\log(1+e^{-y\hat{f}(x)})\)}}.
In one-vs-rest, we try to learn classes by {{c1::relabeling points from all classes except one as \(-1\) and the one from that class as \(1\).}}
The ROC curve plots the {{c1::TPR (True Positive Rate)}} against the {{c2::FPR (False Positive Rate)}}.
AUROC stands for {{c1::Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic (curve)}}.
Ideally, the AUROC is equal to {{c1::\(1\)}}.
A pooling layer helps by {{c1::reducing the width of the network / number of parameters}}.
A prior (distribution) is an {{c1::assumed probability distribution before some evidence is taken into account}}.
We call Gaussian Naive Bayes naive because it assumes that {{c1::every pair of features is conditionally independent}}.
Weakly-typed languages do {{c1::classify values into types}}, but do not {{c1::enforce additional restrictions}}.
Strongly-typed languages enforce that {{c1::all arguments to an operation have the correct types}}.
A type is a {{c1::set of values sharing some properties}}.
In static type checking, we determine {{c1::at compile time}} if a program is correctly typed.
In dynamic type checking, we determine {{c1::at run time}} if the arguments to an operation are of the expected type.
The type invariant for statically type-safe OOP language is "{{c1::In every program state, the value of the variable v is an element of the declared type of v.}}"
Gradual Typing is {{c1::optional static type checking}} for dynamically-typed languages.
Two examples for gradual typing are {{c1::TypeScript for JavaScript and mypy for Python}}.
Duck typing is an informal name for {{c1::structural dynamic type systems}}.
A persona is {{c1::a precise description of a user as a stand-in for a real user}}.
With the analytical method, we look at {{c1::inherent attributes of the design rather than seeing the design in use}}.
With the empirical method, we look at {{c1::how a design (change) affects observable usage}}.

There are five principal components to Usability:
  • {{c1::Learnability}}
  • {{c1::Efficiency}}
  • {{c1::Memorability}}
  • {{c1::Errors}}
  • {{c1::Satisfaction}}
An affordance is an {{c1::action that the design of an object suggests to a user}}.
KLM stands for {{c1::Keystroke Level Model}}.
Priming means that {{c1::we ask questions that already imply a certain answer}}.
